    By Shaswat Gupta LinkedIn Email

    Executive Summary

    Switzerland’s startup ecosystem – particularly around ETH Zurich – is thriving, with AI at its core. ETH Zurich’s spin-offs enjoy remarkable success rates, underpinned by deep research foundations and a supportive entrepreneurial infrastructure.

    Google Cloud’s “Future of AI: Perspectives for Startups 2025” outlines critical AI trends (from agentic AI to infrastructure and investor priorities) shaping startup strategies.
    This report distills these trends and ties them to Switzerland’s venture landscape:

    • AI Trends for Startups — GenAI-driven AI agents and infrastructure modernization are front-of-mind. Investors emphasize real-world solutions and sustainable “AI + X” use-cases.

    • ETH Zurich Spin-Offs — ETH produced 37 spin-offs in 2024 (580+ total since 1973), with a 93% five-year survival rate and cumulative funding reaching CHF 425 M. ETH spin-offs boast four unicorns, growing diversity (35% with female co-founders), and increasing exits and venture rounds.

    • Startup Infrastructure at ETH — A vibrant pipeline of programs fuels startup formation:

      • ETH Entrepreneur Club events (Launch, InCube, Speed Dating)
      • ETH Juniors’ jFund seed grants
      • BOOST accelerator (CHF 40k+ prize)
      • Student Project House makerspaces, labs, and seed funding

    Notice: ETH Zurich offers a uniquely dense and structured ecosystem — from ideation to investment — empowering students and researchers alike.

    Funding & Sector Overview
    Swiss startups raised CHF 2.3 B in 2024 across ~513 deals.

    • Health/Biotech led with CHF 1.0 B (~45% share)
    • Software/Analytics followed with CHF 397 M (~17%)
    • AI-centric startups doubled their deal count to 113 rounds and saw a +134% surge in funding (CHF 345 M) — even as overall VC volume dipped.
      Notable AI startups include:
    • Lakera (~CHF 17 M, AI security)
    • EthonAI (~CHF 15 M, industrial AI)
    • Jua (~CHF 14 M, climate/AI)
    • Prem Labs (~CHF 12 M, AI)

    Recent Startup Activity & Headlines

    Despite macro headwinds, ETH spin-offs and Swiss AI startups are securing notable rounds:

    • Unique (ETH spinoff, AI for finance) — Raised $30 M Series A for agentic AI copilots in banking and insurance.
      Offers AI agents for KYC, investment research, due diligence.
      👉 Read on TechCrunch

    • Cerrion (ETH AI, industrial automation) — Raised $5 M seed from YC and Goat Capital.
      Applies video AI to manufacturing; reduces faults using CCTV-based monitoring.

    • Logic Star AI (ETH/INSAIT spin-off) — Raised €2.9 M pre-seed led by Northzone.
      Builds autonomous software agents for self-healing code maintenance.

    • Cradle (AI biotech, ETH ties) — Raised $73 M Series B for its protein-design platform.
      Uses AI to help pharma companies iterate faster on proteins.

    • Calvin Risk (ETH spin-off, AI governance) — Raised $4 M seed to expand its AI risk management platform.
      Helps enterprises monitor AI “black box” behavior under EU AI Act.

    • ETH AI/Biotech highlights —

      • Neustark (carbon capture): ~$69 M
      • Bright Peak (immunotherapy): ~$90 M
      • Terensis (agri-AI), CellX (biotech for pollution): represent deep-tech diversity

    New: ETH’s AI activity spans infrastructure, governance, healthcare, and climate — establishing leadership in “AI for real-world impact.”

    International Recognition
    WIRED (2024) named Zurich a hotspot for:

    • AI language learning startups
    • Medtech robotics
    • Next-gen battery companies

    ETH spin-offs featured:

    • Decentriq (data clean rooms)
    • LatticeFlow (AI robustness testing)

    Switzerland continues to produce unicorns (e.g., Scandit, Climeworks, South Pole, GetYourGuide) and attract global attention for AI-driven innovation.

    Important: The ETH ecosystem isn’t just growing — it’s winning visibility and validation on the global stage.

    1. AI Trends for Startups (Google Cloud’s 2025 Report)

    Generative AI (GenAI) Momentum — Startups are the engine of GenAI innovation in 2025, rapidly creating new applications and business models. Google Cloud’s “Future of AI: Perspectives for Startups 2025” gathered insights from 23 AI leaders to chart this path. Key themes include:

    • Rise of AI Agents — An “agentic AI” movement is underway. Unlike simple chatbots, AI agents can make decisions, execute tasks, and act autonomously. Experts predict AI agents evolving from task-specific helpers to “ambient agents”, always-on digital assistants that proactively handle background tasks.
      👉 Read: What’s next in AI for startups | Google Cloud Blog
      For example, Harrison Chase (LangChain CEO) envisions agents monitoring events and only alerting humans when intervention is needed.
      👉 See quote from LangChain CEO

    New: This shift marks a fundamental evolution in AI usage — from reactive tools to proactive collaborators.

    Important: Ambient agents may redefine how humans interact with software, shifting from task-execution to delegation and trust in autonomy.

    • Emotional Intelligence — Next-gen AI will better understand human emotions and intent. Matthieu Rouif (Photoroom) and Jia Li (LiveX AI) foresee AI tailoring content to user emotions and truly grasping customer intent – making interactions feel “more human than mechanical.”

    Notice: Emotional intelligence in AI is no longer a luxury — it’s becoming a product differentiator.

    • AI Infrastructure & Integration — Breakthrough AI needs breakthrough infrastructure. With skyrocketing compute demands for AI models, startups must architect systems for flexibility and scale. Amin Vahdat (Google Cloud) notes “never-seen-before” compute density requirements, pushing modular model architectures and robust observability. Startups should plan for **plug-and-play model upgrades to avoid constant overhauls.
      Key insight: Building AI into real business workflows, with strong observability and A/B testing vs. existing processes, is vital (per Mayada Gonimah, Thread AI CTO).

    Important: Infrastructure is not just a backend concern — it’s a strategic moat for long-term scale.

    • Investor Priorities — In 2025, VCs and angels refocus on AI startups solving concrete problems. No more “AI-for-AI’s sake”: Investors seek applied AI in health, climate, housing, etc. (Salim Teja, Radical Ventures). They value high-quality proprietary data moats, productivity gains (especially dev tools), and clear ROI over hype.
      Crystal Huang (GV) says: “If your product is easy to implement, it’s just as easy to uninstall” — meaning successful AI products must become indispensable, deeply integrated in workflows.
      In short, “stickiness” and path to profitability trump novelty.

    Notice: Investors in 2025 care more about traction and defensibility than technical elegance alone.

    • Competitive Moats — To leapfrog competition, startups need more than wrapping a generic LLM behind an interface. Yoav Shoham (AI21 Labs) urges teams to find “Product–Algo Fit” – leverage today’s best models in clever ways rather than waiting for future improvements.
      David Friedberg (Ohalo Genetics) warns against being just an “LLM wrapper” – sustainable AI ventures will have an “engine of value” like proprietary data or network effects that continuously improve the AI.

    • Looking Ahead Responsibly — The GenAI revolution’s pace is unprecedented. Google Cloud’s report concludes with a call for responsible AI collaboration – ensuring infrastructure, tooling, and guidance keep up so startups can harness AI ethically and effectively.
      Founders are advised to capitalize on resources like cloud credits (up to $350k) and expert consultations.

    Important: Speed must be matched with responsibility — ethics and governance will determine long-term viability in AI.

    Takeaway — For Swiss AI startups (and their investors) in 2025, the bar is high: those who combine cutting-edge AI (agents, LLMs) with real-world utility and strong execution will lead. ETH Zurich’s talent pool and tech focus align well with these trends, helping local startups build responsibly and ambitiously.

    2. ETH Zurich Spin-Offs – 2024 Data & Achievements

    ETH Zurich has cultivated one of Europe’s most prolific academic startup ecosystems. The ETH Spin-Off Report 2024 reveals the scale and success of this pipeline:

    • Record Launches — 2024 saw 37 new ETH spin-offs, slightly below 2022’s record but extending a long-term growth trend. Many of 2024’s spin-offs target AI (10) and biotech/pharma (8) – the top two domains.
      Examples: Terensis – uses satellites + AI in agriculture to predict crop yields.
      CellX – biotech tackling PFAS and microplastics with pollutant-eating bacteria.

    Notice: ETH’s spin-off output consistently targets frontier sectors, showcasing how research translates directly into impactful ventures.

    • Survival & Scale — An incredible 93% of ETH spin-offs survive 5+ years, far exceeding typical startup rates. As of early 2025, ETH spin-offs total 580+ companies since 1973, with 519 still active in Switzerland.
      This longevity underscores ETH’s supportive environment and strong founder preparation.

    Important: ETH’s spin-offs aren’t just numerous — they’re resilient. A 93% survival rate sets a global benchmark.

    • Funding Boom — ETH spin-offs raised CHF 425 M in 2024 (42 financing rounds) – a +25% jump YoY, and 10x growth versus a decade ago. The report notes a tenfold increase in annual investment since 2014.
      Flagship 2024 fundraises:
      Neustark (climate tech) – ~$69 M for CO₂ capture in concrete.
      Bright Peak Therapeutics (biotech) – ~$90 M for protein-based immunotherapies.
      These large rounds signal that ETH spin-offs are scaling beyond seed stage, attracting global VC interest.

    • Unicorns & Exits — ETH Zurich has birthed 4 unicorns to date:
      GetYourGuide (travel platform, founded 2008) – unicorn in 2019
      Scandit (comp. vision barcode scanning, 2009) – unicorn in 2022
      Climeworks (direct air capture, 2009) – unicorn in 2022
      South Pole (carbon finance, 2008) – unicorn in 2022
      In 2024 alone, ETH spin-offs had 8 exits via acquisition – e.g., ABB’s purchase of Sevensense (robotics) and Oxford Instruments buying FemtoTools (precision instruments).
      Exits and unicorns provide capital recycling and alumni mentorship, fueling the ecosystem.

    New: Exits and unicorns are not just success metrics — they feed back into ETH’s founder pipeline through mentorship, funding, and credibility.

    • Global yet Local — ETH spin-off founders are internationally diverse (46 nationalities since 2017; ~55% non-Swiss), but importantly >99% of spin-offs stay in Switzerland.
      This “brain capture” reflects Switzerland’s attractiveness for business (IP rights, grants, quality of life).
      The ETH network helps foreign founders navigate incorporation and local growth, benefiting the Swiss economy through job creation and innovation.

    Notice: ETH retains global talent locally — a strategic advantage for Switzerland’s innovation economy.

    • Diversity Progress — Female founders are rising. In 2024, 14% of spin-off founders were women and 35% of new spin-offs had mixed-gender teams.
      While all-female founder teams remain rare, the trend of mixed teams is encouraging, showing ETH’s efforts (like Women in Tech initiatives) are gaining traction.
      The Student Project House and targeted programs help broaden participation.

    • Domains & Departments — Top ETH departments spinning off companies are Mechanical & Process Engineering (D-MAVT) and Information Tech & Electrical Eng. (D-ITET) – aligning with strengths in robotics, AI, medtech.
      Fewer spin-offs originate in purely theoretical fields (e.g., Math had the fewest).
      This suggests a strong link between applied research and entrepreneurship at ETH.
      On the industry side, AI/software and biotech/medtech dominate recent spin-offs, often converging (e.g., ETH AI in healthcare imaging).

    Important: Applied research isn’t just impactful — it’s the heartbeat of ETH’s entrepreneurial ecosystem.

    Bottom Line — ETH Zurich’s spin-off engine combines world-class research, founder-friendly culture, and strong institutional backing – yielding startups that not only launch in record numbers but thrive and scale.
    For investors, ETH spin-offs represent de-risked, high-potential bets given their survival stats and deep IP; for founders, ETH offers a model launchpad with resources from lab to market.

    3. Startup Infrastructure at ETH Zurich

    ETH Zurich’s entrepreneurial success isn’t accidental – it’s supported by a rich infrastructure of clubs, funds, and facilities that guide founders from student to CEO.

    ETH Entrepreneur Club: Inspire, Educate, Accelerate

    A student-driven powerhouse, the ETH Entrepreneur Club (EC) connects aspiring founders with resources, mentorship, and each other. Key activities:

    • Launch (Startup Fair & Conference) — Co-hosted with SICTIC (investor network), Launch is ETH’s annual startup showcase (e.g., Oct 2024 at ETH Zentrum). It mixes an expo of 40+ startups, “Founders meet Industry” sessions, workshops, and a Startup-Investor matchmaking lounge.
      Scale: 1000+ students, 200+ investors, and corporates gather – making Launch a prime networking event to ignite partnerships and funding for ETH ventures.

    • InCube (Global Challenge) — A unique 5-day hackathon where students literally live in a glass cube to ideate solutions.
      👉 InCube Challenge | Think Inside the Box
      InCube is an international innovation competition – open to students worldwide (ETH covers expenses). Multidisciplinary teams tackle a challenge while cohabiting in a public cube, an intense experience fostering creativity and resilience.
      The finale at Launch crowns a winner. InCube serves as a gateway to entrepreneurship for young talent, often sparking new startup ideas and multicultural collaboration.

    New: InCube transforms passive learners into immersive problem-solvers through a one-of-a-kind experiential format.

    • Startup Speed Dating — A one-evening event where startups meet 1:1 with students in a rapid “speed date” format. Typically held each semester (e.g., May 2024), it attracted ~120 students and 30 startups in past editions.
      Impact: Many ETH spin-offs made their first key hires through Speed Dating, injecting fresh talent and giving students real startup exposure.

    Notice: Startup Speed Dating is more than networking — it’s a tested pipeline for talent acquisition in early-stage ventures.

    • RocketHub Incubator — A startup co-working and incubator space run by the EC.
      👉 RocketHub by ETH Entrepreneur Club
      Located near campus, RocketHub offers 30+ startups access to makerspace, coworking desks, a mentorship program, and events/workshops.
      Notably, membership is nearly free (CHF 50/semester plus a small coworking fee per team size) – ensuring even bootstrapped student teams can afford it. RocketHub cultivates an on-campus startup community where teams share knowledge and get hands-on support.

    Important: RocketHub functions as ETH’s internal “pre-accelerator” — lowering the barrier to entry for student-led innovation.

    • JoinUp (Startup Jobs Platform) — Launched in 2023 by ETH EC and Swisspreneur, JoinUp is Switzerland’s free startup job portal.
      It bridges startups needing talent with students/grads seeking entrepreneurial jobs.
      Key features:
      • Free job postings for startups, free applications for candidates
      • ETH EC promotion ensures broad reach in the student community
      • Direct contact: Startups get notified when candidates apply, streamlining hiring (no HR middleman)
        JoinUp strengthens the talent pipeline, helping keep ETH-trained talent in the local startup scene rather than corporates.

    In sum, the ETH Entrepreneur Club’s offerings – from inspiration events (Launch) to hands-on programs (RocketHub, Speed Dating) – create a full-spectrum support system.
    They inspire students (talks, InCube), educate them (workshops, hackathons), and accelerate early startups (incubation, investor links). For VCs, EC events like Launch and the Startup Speed Dating are prime places to spot promising teams early.

    ETH juniors & jFund: Student Consulting Meets Funding

    ETH juniors is a student-run consultancy (a “junior enterprise”) that hires ETH students to do projects for industry. It’s unique because it plows profits back into supporting student founders:

    • jFund (ETH juniors Fund) — Established in 2015 by ETH juniors and the ETH Seniors alumni club, jFund provides seed money grants to ETH students launching startups.
      Only ETH juniors alumni (former members) can apply, ensuring the recipients have already proven themselves via juniors. It’s a micro-VC for student founders.
      • Often first money in (pre-seed grants)
      • Leverages an alumni network for mentorship alongside funding
        While amounts are modest (CHF 5–25k range), jFund can be pivotal at concept stage.

    Notice: ETH juniors recycles consulting profit into startup grants — a virtuous loop between applied skills and entrepreneurship.

    • Boost (Pre-incorporation Accelerator) — BOOST is a new (since 2023) accelerator program co-hosted by ETH juniors and the EC.
      It targets ETH-affiliated startups before or just at incorporation.
      • ~10 early teams are selected and matched with mentors
      • Intensive workshops and coaching run for several weeks
      • Culminates in a Final Pitch Competition (e.g., May 5, 2025 at ETH HG Hall)
        👉 BOOST Event Info
      • Prizes: 2025 offers CHF 40k prize pool plus in-kind legal packages (incorporation, IP, etc.)

      BOOST fills a gap between ideation and raising seed funding. By focusing on incorporation readiness (business case refinement, term sheets, legal structure), it bridges academia to company formation.

    Important: BOOST turns student ideas into investor-ready companies — at the ideal inflection point.

    ETH juniors Consulting — Indirectly, ETH juniors benefits startups by training future founders.
    Students who run juniors learn to manage projects, handle clients, and think entrepreneurially – skills directly transferable to launching a venture.
    Many ETH juniors alumni indeed start companies, which the jFund then seeds. It’s a virtuous cycle of consulting → funding → founding → reinvestment.

    Student Project House (SPH): Makerspace & Idea Accelerator

    ETH’s Student Project House is a creativity lab open to all students – a sandbox to tinker and prototype:

    • Facilities — SPH offers makerspaces with advanced equipment (3D printers, laser cutters, electronics labs) and co-working areas.
      Students can get free access to build prototypes or hardware for their startup ideas.

    • Seed Funding & Coaching — SPH runs programs like Spark or Ignition Grants – small funds (CHF 5–10k) for early-stage student projects.
      They emphasize learning by doing, not equity or IP. Coaches (students or staff) also mentor teams on project management and design thinking.

    • Community & Events — Regular meetups, idea-pitch nights, and “Ask the Expert” sessions foster a maker community.
      Projects at SPH range from social impact tech to AI-driven gadgets.
      Teams can join SPH early, then graduate to RocketHub or apply to BOOST as they formalize.

    • Example Projects — A team developing water quality sensors (like Riverkin, mentioned in 2024 highlights) can prototype at SPH, get initial funding, and eventually spin out if viable.

    New: SPH serves as ETH’s sandbox — bridging theory with messy, hands-on creativity that launches ideas into reality.

    Additional ETH Resources

    ETH’s ecosystem extends further:

    • ETH Zurich Foundation & Fundraising — Matches startups with industry sponsors or philanthropists (e.g., bridge grants, competition prizes)

    • IP & Tech Transfer (ETH transfer) — A dedicated office helps spin-offs license ETH-owned IP and file patents. Critical for deeptech.

    • Entrepreneurship Courses — ETH offers lectures on startup topics, often with VC guest speakers or founder alumni. UZH collaborations deepen academic-industry engagement.

    Summary — At ETH, a student can ideate at SPH, validate in an EC hackathon, get early funding from jFund, incubate at RocketHub, accelerate via BOOST, and showcase at Launch – all within the campus network.
    This end-to-end support significantly de-risks startup formation and growth.
    For investors, ETH startups are often better prepared and vetted.
    For corporates, the ecosystem provides a steady stream of spin-outs for potential partnerships or acquisitions.

    4. Funding and Sector Overview

    Switzerland’s startup funding landscape in 2024–25 has seen mixed fortunes – a slight downturn in volume, but bright spots in certain sectors, especially AI and biotech.

    Overall Funding Climate

    • Total Funding Decline — Swiss startups raised ~CHF 2.3 B in 2024, down ~15% from 2023. This marks the second year of decline from the 2021–2022 boom (2022 was ~CHF 3.9 B).
      Contributing factors:
      • Macro-economic tightening (higher interest rates, VC caution)
      • Lack of mega-rounds (>CHF 200 M); more conservative follow-ons
      • However, H2 2024 showed slight recovery vs H1, hinting the bottom may be behind us

    Notice: Despite macro pressures, the Swiss ecosystem is showing signs of stabilization — especially in H2 2024.

    • Deal Count — 513 funding rounds in 2024 (vs 550 in 2023, –6.7%). The decline was sharper in H2 (225 deals) compared to H1 (288), reflecting a summer slowdown. By early 2025, investors seem more optimistic, especially in high-tech verticals.

    • Round Sizes — Fewer blockbuster rounds but healthy seed/Series A activity. A notable trend is many smaller AI startups getting funded.
      Implication: VCs spread bets in AI and biotech, while growth-stage funding is more scarce except for top performers.

    Sector Breakdown

    1. Health & Biotech

    • Dominant in Capital — Health-related startups (biotech, medtech, digital health, etc.) raised ~CHF 1.0 B in 2024 – about 45% of all Swiss startup investment.
      Biotech alone took 68% of health’s share (~CHF 680 M) across 63 deals.

    • Top Deals — Multiple biotech startups (many in Basel/Zurich arc) closed CHF 50–150 M rounds.
      Notable names: Anokion (autoimmune therapy), various CRISPR-focused firms.

    • Medtech & Healthtech — Medtech raised ~CHF 275 M (51 deals). Digital health also contributed, but biotech’s capital intensity led.
      ETH highlight: SulzerSENSE (Series B in health sensing).

    • Outlook — Strong fundamentals due to Switzerland’s pharma base.
      VCs remain bullish on biotech despite long R&D cycles.

    Important: Biotech dominates not just in value, but in shaping Switzerland’s global innovation brand.

    2. Software & AI

    • Deal Leader — Software & analytics had 153 deals (most of any sector), surpassing health’s 135.
      Total funding ~CHF 397 M (17% share). Includes B2B SaaS, fintech, and AI-enabled platforms.

    • AI as a Cross-Cutting Theme — AI startups saw 113 deals (up 2x) and CHF 345 M invested (up 134%).
      AI appeared across verticals (health, fintech, analytics). ETH examples:
      LatticeFlow (AI model validation, ~$12 M), Reframe.ai (AI scheduling)

    • Fintech/Insurtech — Fintech funding dropped ~51% to ~CHF 206 M.
      Later-stage firms paused raises, but early-stage fintechs (esp. crypto/blockchain, B2B tools) remained active.
      Notable players: Neon, Relai

    • Notable Swiss AI startups —
      Lakera (AI security auditing)
      EthonAI (industrial AI, ETH spin-off)
      Jua (weather AI)
      Each raised ~CHF 12–17 M in 2024.

    New: AI is no longer a niche — it’s embedded across sectors and driving Swiss venture momentum.

    3. Hardware & Deep Tech

    • Hardware Startups — Made up ~7% of funding. Focus areas: robotics, semiconductors, IoT.
      ETH spin-offs: SynSense (neuromorphic chips), Sevensense (robot vision, acquired by ABB)

    • Energy Tech — Breakout category: +362% growth in rounds.
      ETH examples: Neustark, Climeworks (carbon capture)

    • Others — AgriTech/FoodTech fell 68% from 2023 highs.
      Media, mobility, etc. also cooled. Focus is sharpening on core tech sectors.

    Notice: Switzerland’s deep tech playbook is evolving — with ETH spin-offs leading energy and robotics.

    4. Exits & Late Stage

    • Fewer IPOs or unicorn births in 2024; instead, strategic M&A exits (e.g., ETH spin-off acquisitions).

    • Still, pipeline strength remains:

      • Public success stories: SOPHiA Genetics, On
      • Unicorn watchlist: Scandit, Climeworks, WeFox, MindMaze

    Subsector Spotlights

    • Biotech vs. Medtech —
      Biotech = large rounds, long timelines.
      Medtech = more frequent, smaller rounds.
      ETH contributions: CUTISS (skin biotech), Nanoflex (nanotech sensors)

    • Fintech & Crypto —
      Despite funding dip, Crypto Valley (Zug) remains vibrant.
      Series A/B rounds still land for blockchain startups.

    • AI & Data Startups —
      Many now pitch as “AI + X”:
      • Decentriq (AI + data privacy)
      • Squirro (AI insights)
        Often research-rooted from ETH/EPFL.
    • Cleantech —
      Carbon capture, sustainable materials are rising. ETH examples:
      • Meteomatics (weather data, €21 M raised)
    • Venture Capital Trends —
      Swiss VCs (e.g., Swisscom Ventures, VI Partners) co-invest with global funds.
      • Northzone led LogicStar’s round
      • DN Capital led Unique’s
        Global VC attention is focused on ETH spin-offs.

    Key Insight for Founders/Investors —
    The Swiss startup scene in 2025 is sector-polarized: deeptech and health attract patient capital; consumer or local-only plays struggle.
    AI is a golden thread, enhancing ventures across verticals.
    To win, teams must build a credible moat — in data, tech, or execution.
    ETH founders should double down on their technical edge — it’s the Swiss ecosystem’s biggest strength.

    5. Recent Startup Activity & Headlines

    The past year has produced headline-grabbing deals and innovations in the Swiss & ETH startup community. Here are highlights, with context:

    • Unique – AI Agents for Finance
      “Zurich-based Unique raises $30M Series A” – TechCrunch, Feb 2025
      An ETH Zurich spin-off (founded 2021), Unique builds a platform of agentic AI co-workers for banks. This “AI workforce” can handle tasks from KYC checks to summarizing investment research, acting as a copilot for knowledge workers.
      👉 Read on TechCrunch
      The term “agentic AI” (one of 2025’s big buzzwords) aligns perfectly with Unique’s pitch. Their traction — blue-chip Swiss banks as clients — convinced DN Capital and CommerzVentures to lead the round.
      Unique’s funding now totals ~€50 M. The startup is cited as a category-definer in vertical AI, attracting top talent like a Google DeepMind PM who joined as CPO.

    New: Unique shows how ETH spin-offs can lead the charge in specialized AI applications for regulated industries.

    • Cerrion – Industrial Automation AI
      “AI-powered automation startup Cerrion raises $5M” – Tech.eu, Sept 2024
      Co-founded by ETH alum Karim Saleh (ex-Egypt water polo captain turned engineer), Cerrion uses computer vision to monitor factories through existing cameras.
      The $5M seed — led by Y Combinator and Goat Capital — is notable, as YC rarely leads. Cerrion graduated YC S22 and already operates in 8 countries, delivering 30%+ reduction in factory losses.

    Important: Cerrion embodies how Swiss startups can combine AI with industrial know-how to create scalable, hardware-integrated solutions.

    • LogicStar AI – Self-Healing Software
      “LogicStar secures $3M pre-seed (spin-off from INSAIT & ETHZ)” – The Recursive, Feb 2025
      Bridging Zurich and Sofia, LogicStar is building AI agents to autonomously fix software bugs and maintain code.
      The team includes ETH’s Prof. Martin Vechev, a leader in program analysis. Northzone’s backing at pre-seed shows confidence in the vision and tech.
      Implication: ETH’s labs are not just producing apps — they’re launching “hard tech” AI tools that could change software ops.

    Notice: ETH’s influence extends into foundational AI infrastructure — with LogicStar pushing boundaries in DevOps autonomy.

    • Cradle – Generative Biotech
      “Cradle raises $73M for protein-design AI” – TechCrunch, Nov 2024
      Though based in Amsterdam, Cradle has Swiss team ties and sits at the AI–biotech frontier. It uses AI (including LLMs for protein sequences) to suggest genetic or protein edits, drastically reducing trial cycles.
      ETH’s strengths in bioengineering suggest similar ventures may follow. Cradle’s fast rise (2022 → $73M B-round in 2 years) shows how fast deeptech can scale when it hits product–market fit.

    New: Cradle validates a huge opportunity at the intersection of AI and wet-lab biotech — one ETH is well positioned to pursue.

    • Calvin Risk – AI Governance
      “Calvin Risk (ETH spin-off) raises $4M for AI risk platform” – EU-Startups / Forbes, Nov 2024
      Calvin Risk builds real-time AI risk management software, tackling compliance, model transparency, and bias.
      Their raise coincides with the upcoming EU AI Act, which mandates governance — perfect timing.
      Clients include major insurers and financial firms; investors include Join Capital and Seed+Speed.

    Important: Calvin Risk is turning Swiss trust in compliance into a global AI governance product — right as regulations catch up.

    • Other Noteworthy Startups

      • Meteomatics (St. Gallen) – Raised €21 M for weather data analytics, powering sectors like aviation and energy
      • Oxyle (ETH spin-off) – Raised €15.3 M to clean water via nanotech
      • SAEKI (Zug) – €6.4 M for autonomous factory robotics, tapping into Switzerland’s hardware edge
      • Invasight (ETH spin-off) – Won 2024 W.A. De Vigier Award for AI-powered cancer drug discovery
      • Peers of Unique: Starmind (AI knowledge networks), Squirro (AI analytics) continue raising and scaling globally

    Notice: These ventures span weather tech, water purification, robotics, and precision medicine — showcasing the deep breadth of Swiss and ETH startup DNA.

    • Media Recognition
      The WIRED “Europe’s 100 Hottest Startups 2024” list spotlighted Zurich for fintech, robotics, and AI.
      ETH-linked startups featured:
      • Decentriq – secure data collaboration (“Switzerland of data”)
      • LatticeFlow – AI robustness testing
      • Verity – indoor drone inventory
        Fintech News and venturelab regularly list ETH spin-offs like Unique, ranked #32 in the Top 100 Swiss Startups 2023.

    Summary — The Swiss and ETH startup scene is maturing fast:

    • Seed-stage activity is healthy (LogicStar, Calvin Risk)
    • Series A/B momentum is strong for those with traction (Unique, Cradle)
    • Strategic exits and unicorn alumni (e.g., Sevensense, Climeworks) are cementing the ecosystem

    The common thread: deep technology solving real, high-stakes problems — in finance, biotech, infrastructure, and compliance.

    About the Author

    Shaswat Gupta is an MS Computer Science student at ETH Zurich, and a rank 1 gold medalist from IIT Bombay. With hands-on experience as an ML engineer at organizations like the World Bank, AB InBev, ISB, and startups, Shaswat specializes in machine learning, scalable engineering, and data-driven solutions. Known for his analytical rigor combined with a creative flair in music, poetry, journalism, and public speaking, Shaswat loves tackling challenging problems and welcomes exciting collaborations.

    6. Miscellaneous Data Points & Resources

    To round out the picture, here are a few additional data points and resources relevant to Swiss and ETH startups:

    • ETH Spin-off Historical Data — Since formal tracking in 1973, ETH has produced over 580 spin-offs.
      On average, ~20+ per year in the 2010s, now ~30+ per year.
      ETH spin-offs by sector (2020 study):
      • ~30% in ICT (software/AI)
      • ~20% in medtech/biotech
      • Rest in cleantech, advanced materials, etc.

    Notice: ETH’s spin-off pipeline shows consistent and increasing productivity — with a clear tilt toward tech-heavy domains.

    • Top-Funded Swiss Startups (all-time) — Many have ETH roots:
      • Climeworks (~$800 M total funding) – carbon capture
      • GetYourGuide (~$883 M) – travel platform
      • On (~$740 M before IPO) – sports shoes (ETH alum founded)
      • SonarSource (~$457 M) – code analysis (Geneva, not ETH)
      • Wefox (~$1.3 B) – insurtech (ETH co-founder)

      These figures show Swiss startups can raise at scale when scaling globally, often requiring international capital participation.

    Important: Swiss startups aren’t just regional players — they compete globally with the backing of deep tech and strong founder pipelines.

    • Venture Capital & Accelerators — In addition to ETH’s internal infrastructure, many founders also access:

      • Innosuisse — Swiss Innovation Agency grants for R&D and coaching
      • Venture Kick — CHF 150k pre-seed grants + training
      • Venturelab’s TOP 100 — National ranking + networking events
      • MassChallenge Switzerland (Lausanne) and F10 (Zurich fintech) — open incubators and accelerators
      • Corporate Innovation Challenges — e.g., UBS’s Future of Finance, SwissRe’s InsurTech accelerator

    New: Non-dilutive capital from Swiss and EU programs provides early risk capital without equity dilution — a unique advantage in Europe.

    • Media & Information Hubs — Keeping up with Swiss startup news and recognition:

      • TechCrunch and EU-Startups — now frequently cover Swiss deals
      • The Recursive — covers ETH’s Eastern European ties (e.g., LogicStar)
      • Startupticker.ch — daily Swiss startup digest (English/German)
      • Fintechnews.ch — industry-specific analysis (especially AI & fintech)
      • Wired and Forbes — feature Swiss startups in broader EU context
      • ETH News — highlights ETH entrepreneurship stories (e.g., “Start-up boom thriving”)

    Notice: Swiss startups are enjoying increasing international visibility — which helps attract talent, capital, and partnerships.

    • Notable Lists
      • TOP 100 Swiss Startups Award — curated by investors, tracking rising stars.
        Recent ETH highlights: Scrona (nanotech), CREAL (AR displays), Synhelion (solar fuels)
      • W.A. de Vigier Awards — premier early-stage competition. ETH spin-offs often win (e.g., Animatico, Microcaps)
      • EU Horizon Grants / EIC Accelerator — non-dilutive deeptech grants. ETH’s Microcaps secured €2.5 M.

    Important: These rankings and grants shape both perception and access — often catalyzing credibility for further raises.

    Conclusion – Major Takeaways

    Switzerland’s AI and deeptech startup scene, anchored by ETH Zurich, is entering a new stage of maturity:

    • AI is pervasive — not only birthing new startups (AI for X) but supercharging legacy sectors like finance, manufacturing, and biotech.
      Startups like Unique and LogicStar reflect how ETH talent is driving this AI wave with domain-specific solutions.

    Important: AI is no longer a vertical — it’s the backbone of Swiss innovation across multiple sectors.

    • ETH Zurich’s ecosystem works — A case study in translating research into high-impact companies.
      The numbers speak volumes: 93% survival rate, CHF hundreds of millions raised, and a deep support infrastructure (Entrepreneur Club, jFund, SPH, etc.).

    Notice: ETH Zurich reduces startup risk through dense institutional support — a model other ecosystems are studying.

    • Sector strengths — Switzerland leads in biotech/health and fintech, but is now emerging as a hub for AI governance and industrial AI.
      Founders should strategically align with these pockets of excellence to gain momentum.

    • Funding outlook — Although 2024 saw fewer mega-deals, AI deals doubled in volume.
      As capital flows return in 2025–26, many ETH-born ventures will be ready for breakout Series B/C rounds.

    New: The downturn reshuffled priorities — favoring capital-efficient, technically strong, and execution-focused teams.

    • Globalization — Swiss startups are global from day one:
      • International founding teams
      • Cross-border VC participation
      • Global customer bases
        From Unique’s multinational clients to Calvin’s EU-aligned compliance tools, borders aren’t bottlenecks anymore.
    • Sustainable Innovation — ETH spin-offs often tackle systemic problems — from climate to automation.
      Profit aligns with purpose, attracting impact investors and corporate partners looking for meaningful innovation.

    Important: ETH ventures are increasingly solving “wicked problems” — combining deeptech with global relevance.

    For venture capitalists, the Swiss AI startup ecosystem offers technically robust, founder-resilient companies from a proven and de-risked pipeline.
    Engaging early — via ETH demo days, hackathons, or research collaborations — can yield differentiated deal flow.

    For startup founders, ETH Zurich provides a launchpad that integrates academia and industry, empowering them to build fast, raise smart, and scale sustainably.

    As we move through 2025, expect ETH Zurich and its spin-offs to keep spearheading innovation in AI, deeptech, and sustainability — keeping Switzerland on the global map as a precision-driven, purpose-aligned Silicon Valley of Europe.

    Sources: Google Cloud’s Future of AI: Perspectives for Startups 2025; ETH Zurich Spin-off Report 2024; ETH News; ETH Entrepreneur Club docs; EY Startup Barometer 2025; TechCrunch, EU-Startups, The Recursive; Wired; Fintechnews.ch.
